Hi Peter

Great demo. Can I take you up on your offer to release the source=
 code for the demos? I'm interested in co-evolutionary approaches with an a=
gent and an antagonistic environment, so your demos would be very interesti=
ng to me.

Regards

Iain 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" =
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken, 
> 
> I am happy that you like my=
 demo. This particular experiment was set 
> up to answer some questions I =
had in mind. The first one is obvious, 
> is there a geometric regularity i=
n the predator/prey task that 
> HyperNEAT can possibly exploit. And there =
is. I can see some 
> meaningful behaviors emerging with HyperNEAT as early=
 as the 4th or 
> 5th generation. My next question was, what is the differe=
nce between 
> the indirect encoding and the direct encoding. Let me make i=
t more 
> clear. In your experiments in the robot duel domain, both robot N=
Ns 
> are encoded directly and complexifying. They elaborate on previous 
>=
 strategies by incrementally adding more structure, right? 
> What about Hy=
perNEAT, does it preserve the same dynamics, where the 
> CPPNs complexify =
but the substrate is fixed? Does it lead to endless 
> alteration of strate=
gies instead of elaboration? I can predict that 
> HyperNEAT can discover s=
ome complex connectivity patterns between 
> hidden nodes to develop some k=
ind of "intelligent" behavior, but is 
> that limited? 
> Well this questio=
n is still not answered because, as you mentioned, 
> the predator/prey tas=
k is too easy to learn, though there is room for 
> the predator and prey t=
o learn tricks to fool each other. For example 
> the prey can learn to hid=
e behind walls, etc. 
> Yes I compared it to direct encoding NEAT and gener=
ally I can conclude 
> that HyperNEAT develops strategies faster. Especiall=
y in the case of 
> many many inputs. Scaling works as well, but it is not =
perfect. 
> Let me tell you about the source code. Unfortunately the core N=
EAT 
> library I wrote and use is locked under an NDA but it is equivalent =
to 
> the rtNEAT modification I released with the NEVH project. The 
> visu=
alization routines are basically the same there, there is nothing 
> new at=
 all. But I can release the source code for the demos 
> themselves. Please=
 ask me about any details, I will be happy to help 
> anyone. 
> 
> Peter
>=
 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
>=
 > Peter, thanks for this HyperNEAT coevolution demo.  I see some
> > inter=
esting behaviors evolving, but I am curious about your own
> > conclusions?=
  What did you learn from this experiment?  Did you try
> > comparing it to=
 regular NEAT in the same domain?  I am not sure
> > whether the difference=
 would be great since I am not sure if this 
> task
> > is sufficiently com=
plex to exhibit a significant difference between
> > the methods.  That is,=
 there is probably only so good that you can 
> get
> > before new skills s=
top really mattering in this domain.
> > 
> > By the way, do you plan relea=
sing source code for your various
> > experiments and AI code?  It seems li=
ke you have a nice system set 
> up
> > and other people might like tinkeri=
ng with it.  I especially like 
> the
> > real-time CPPN/substrate displays=
.
> > 
> > ken
